nodes.text: Machine learning classifiers (KNN, Random Forest, SVM) can be used to detect lung cancer from CT images and comparing their performance will identify the best model for early-stage lung cancer diagnosis
Dataset for training and testing was built primarily from the LIDC-IDRI lung CT scan collection (NIH-NCI) and augmented/validated with samples from AHRC and AIMS hospitals
Image preprocessing applied included CLAHE, Wiener filtering, Adaptive Gaussian filtering, Gaussian and Gabor filtering, resizing from 512x512x3 to 256x, normalization and noise reduction

Models trained: K-Nearest Neighbors (Euclidean distance, K neighbors), Support Vector Machine (max-margin hyperplane), and Random Forest (ensemble of decision trees with bootstrap and feature randomness)
Experimental protocol: 500 images sampled, two labels (NSCLC abnormal vs normal), 70% train / 30% test split, feature extraction and 5-fold cross-validation used for evaluation
A small independent clinical validation set was obtained from AHRC and AIMS and evaluated under radiologist supervision to verify model findings
Performance metrics computed included accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, true positive rate, false positive rate, sensitivity, specificity, AUC, FAR and FRR
SVM achieved the highest average accuracy of 95.06% across 5-fold cross-validation with average precision 0.95, recall 0.99, F1-score 0.98 and average FPR 0.26
KNN achieved average accuracy 86.89% across 5 folds with average precision 0.84, recall 0.98, F1-score 0.91 and average FPR 0.38
Random Forest achieved average accuracy 81.96% across 5 folds with average precision 0.78, recall 0.98, F1-score 0.87 and average FPR 0.48
ROC-AUC values exceeded 0.99 for every class indicating strong class separability in the trained model
Comparative evaluation indicates SVM outperforms KNN and Random Forest on this dataset and experimental setup due to better handling of complex, high-dimensional decision boundaries
The proposed SVM-based system attained higher accuracy (95.05%) than several prior published models (examples: Murphy et al. 84.00%, Messay et al. 82.66%, Gomathi et al. 76.90%, Kumer et al. 86.00%)
Clinical validation with hospital samples and radiologist oversight supports the claim that the diagnostic system can provide accurate and quick diagnosis for physicians

Conclusion: SVM is the most accurate of the evaluated classifiers for early-stage lung cancer detection on the tested dataset; future work should expand and diversify the dataset to improve performance and reliability
